title: Thug Life: Kamal Haasan apologises for delayed Mani Ratnam collaboration
summary: Legendary actor Kamal Haasan has apologized to fans for the 37-year gap between collaborations with director Mani Ratnam. The duo, who last worked together in the 1987 film Nayakan, are now reuniting for Thug Life, scheduled for release on June 5. The announcement came during the launch of the film's single 'Jinguchaa' in Chennai.
content:
Ace director Mani Ratnam and Indian star Kamal Haasan are reuniting on screen after 37 years, marking a significant moment in Indian cinema. Following their 1987 masterpiece Nayakan, the duo is now collaborating on Thug Life, set for a June 5 release.

At the launch event of the film's single 'Jinguchaa' in Chennai, Kamal Haasan addressed the long gap between collaborations. "Nothing has changed between Mani Ratnam and me even after all these years. It's our fault for waiting for so long to come together. We were in search of better scripts and it took this long for us to collaborate," he explained.

Haasan, who has co-written Thug Life with Ratnam, drew parallels between Ratnam's working style and that of his mentor K Balachander. He revealed his nickname for the director - 'Anju ara' Mani Ratnam (meaning 5.30 am Mani Ratnam) - referring to his early morning presence during shoots.

The film features an ensemble cast including Trisha, Silambarasan, Joju George, Ashok Selvan, Nasser, and Abhirami. The project brings together an impressive technical team with music by AR Rahman, cinematography by Ravi K Chandran, and editing by A Sreekar Prasad. The film is a joint production of Raaj Kamal Films International, Madras Talkies, and Red Giant Movies.

Ace directorMani Ratnamand Indian starKamal Haasanreuniting together on screen after a whopping 37 years is headline indeed. After the stunning Nayakan in 1987, the two stalwarts are back together for Thug Life which is all set to release on June 5. On Friday, the Thug Life team launched a single from the film called Jinguchaa was released at an event in Chennai. (Also read:Kamal Haasan reveals the similarity between Mani Ratnam's Thug Life and Nayakan)

Speaking at the event, Kamal Haasan opened up about why the two never got to work together again after Nayakan and even apologised. “Nothing has changed between Mani Ratnam and me even after all these years. It's our fault for waiting for so long to come together. We were in search of better scripts and it took this long for us to collaborate. We are now working together again because of you, the audience - who want us to work together again. We should have collaborated earlier. I’m sorry.”

Kamal Haasan, who has co-written Thug Life with Mani Ratnam, also added that he was reminded of working with renowned director K Balachander, who is his mentor and guru, when he worked with Mani Ratnam. “I am reminded of K Balachander when I see Mani Ratnam’s style of working. He knows what a huge compliment this is. This is our mutual respect. I even have a nickname for Mani Ratnam! ‘Anju ara’ Mani Ratnam (meaning 5.30 am Mani Ratnam) because of how early he was every single day during the shoot,” he said.
